TextView.android:text: Independent Events
In this lesson, we will learn how to find the probability of independent events.
Introduction to lesson
Click on the video to start watching a lecture on the probability of dependent and independent events
Video Source: https://youtu.be/d3SVBUJ3_BR?si=DabaepfwTcS5Phkl

1. landing on heads after tossing a coin AND rolling a 4 on a single six-sided die
2. choosing a marble from a jar AND landing on tails after tossing a coin
3. choosing a jack from a deck of cards, replacing it, AND then choosing a queen as the second card
4. rolling a 3 on a single six-sided die, AND then rolling a 5 on a second roll of the die.
5. tossing a head on two consecutive tosses of the coin
Illustrative Examples

(a) a “3” rolled on the first die and an odd number on the second die?
(b) even number rolled on the first die and a prime number on the second die?
(c) two 5’s in succession?
(d) a factor of 4 on the first die and a multiple of 2 on the second die?
(e) a composite number on the first die and a number less than 3 on the second die?
Show Solution

There are six possible outcomes in a die: 1, 2, 3, 4, 5, 6. There exists one 3 in a die, so the probability of getting a “3” in a first die is 1/6. Since there are 3 odd numbers in a die {1, 3, 5}, the probability of getting an odd number on the second die is 3/6 or 1/2.
The probability of getting a 3 on the first die and an odd number on the second die is 1/12.
(b) Let A be the event that the first die comes up with an even number.\nLet B be the event that the second die comes up with a prime number.

There are six possible outcomes in a die: 1, 2, 3, 4, 5, 6. There exists 3 even numbers in a die {2, 4, 6}, so the probability of getting an “even number” in a first die is 3/6 or 1/2. Since there are prime numbers in a die {2, 3, 5}, the probability of getting a prime number on the second die is 3/6 or 1/2.
The probability of getting an even number on the first die and a prime number on the second die is 1/4.
(c) Let A be the event that the first die comes up 5.\nLet B be the event that the second die comes up 5.
There are six possible outcomes in a die: 1, 2, 3, 4, 5, 6. Since there is one 5 in a die, the probability of getting a “5” on the first die and on the second die is 1/6.
The probability of getting two 5’s in succession in rolling a die is 1/36.
(d) Let A be the event that the first die comes up with a factor of 4.\nLet B be the event that the second die comes up with a multiple of 2.

There are six possible outcomes in a die: 1, 2, 3, 4, 5, 6. There are three factors of 4 {1, 2, 4}, so the probability of getting a “factor of 4” on the first die is 3/6 or 1/2. There are 3 numbers {2, 4, 6} which is a multiple of 2, thus the probability of getting a “multiple of 2” on the second die is 3/6 or 1/2.
The probability of getting a factor of 4 and a multiple of 2 in rolling a die is 1/4.
(e) Let A be the event that the first die comes up with a composite number.\nLet B be the event that the second die comes up with a number less than 3.

There are six possible outcomes in a die: 1, 2, 3, 4, 5, 6. Recall that a composite number is a natural number that has more than three factors. In a die, the numbers 4 and 6 are the only two numbers that have more than 3 factors. Thus, the probability of getting a “composite number” on the first die is 2/6 or 1/3. In a die, the numbers 1 and 2 are two numbers that are less than 3, thus the probability of getting a “number less than 3” on the second die is 2/6 or 1/3.
The probability of getting a composite number and a number less than 3 is 1/9.
(a) she picked the letters “J” and “R”?\n(b) both letters are “L”?\n(c) both letters are vowel?
Show Solution

There are a total of 5 letters in bag 1. There is 1 letter “J”. Thus, the probability of picking the letter “J” is 1/5.\nThere are a total of 6 letters in bag 2. There is 1 letter “R”. Thus, the probability of picking the letter “R” is 1/6.
The probability that Sara picked the letters “J” and “R” is 1/30.
(b) Let A be the event that the letter picked in bag 1 is L.\nLet B be the event that the letter picked in bag 2 is L.

There are a total of 5 letters in bag 1. There is 1 letter “L”. Thus, the probability of picking the letter “L” is 1/5.\nThere are a total of 6 letters in bag 2. There is 1 letter “L”. Thus, the probability of picking the letter “R” is 1/6.
The probability that Sara picked both letters “L” is 1/30.
(c) Let A be the event that the letter picked in bag 1 is a vowel.\nLet B be the event that the letter picked in bag 2 is a vowel.

There are a total of 5 letters in bag 1. There are 3 letters as vowels “I”, “A” and “U”. Thus, the probability of picking the vowel is 3/5.\nThere are a total of 6 letters in bag 2. There are 2 letters as vowels “E” and “A”. Thus, the probability of picking the letter vowel is 2/6 or 1/3
The probability that Sara picked both letters are vowel is 1/5.

(a) a jack and then an ace?
(b) a diamond and red king?
(c) a black card and a queen
(d) a face card and a number card?
(e) a king of hearts and a club?
Show Solution

There are a total of 52 decks of cards. Since there are 4 jack cards, the probability of getting a “jack” is 4/52 or 1/13. Before the second card is drawn, the card was replaced and so the total of the cards remains. Since there are 4 ace cards, the probability of getting an “ace” in a deck of cards is 4/52 or 1/13.
The probability of getting a jack and an ace in a deck of cards is 1/169.
(b) Let A be the event that the card picked is a diamond\nLet B be the event that the card picked is a red king

There are a total of 52 decks of cards. Since there are 13 diamond cards, the probability of getting a “diamond” is 13/52 or 1/4. Before the second card is drawn, the card is replaced and so the total of the cards remains. Since there are 2 red kings {king of diamonds and king of hearts}, the probability of getting a “red king” in a deck of cards is 2/52 or 1/26.
The probability of getting a diamond and a red king in a deck of cards is 1/104.
(c) Let A be the event that the card picked is a black card\nLet B be the event that the card picked is a queen

There are a total of 52 decks of cards. Since there are 26 black cards, the probability of getting a “black card” is 26/52 or 1/2. Before the second card is drawn, the card was replaced and so the total of the cards remains. Since there are 4 queens, the probability of getting a “queen” in a deck of cards is 4/52 or 1/13.
The probability of getting a black card and a queen in a deck of cards is 1/26.
(d) Let A be the event that the card picked is a face card.\nLet B be the event that the card picked is a number card.

There are a total of 52 decks of cards. Since there are 12 face cards {4 jack, 4 queens, 4 kings}, the probability of getting a “face card” is 12/52 or 3/14. Before the second card is drawn, the card is replaced and so the total of the cards remains. Since there are 40 number cards {four each number from ace, 2, 3,...,10}, the probability of getting a “number card” in a deck of cards is 40/52 or 10/13.
The probability of getting a face card and a number in a deck of cards is 15/91.
(e) Let A be the event that the card picked is a king of hearts.\nLet B be the event that the card picked is a club.

There are a total of 52 deck of cards. Since there is only 1 king of hearts, the probability of getting a “king of hearts” is 1/52. Before the second card is drawn, the card was replaced and so the total of the cards remains. Since there are 13 clubs, the probability of getting a “club card” in a deck of cards is 13/52 or 1/4.
The probability of getting a king of hearts and a club in a deck of cards is 1/208.

(a) a “4” and a head?
(b) an odd number and a head?
(c) an even number and a tail?
(d) a prime number and a head?
(e) a factor of 6 and a tail?
Show Solution

There are six possible outcomes in a die: 1, 2, 3, 4, 5, 6. Since there is one 4, so the probability of getting a “4 in a die is 1/6. There are 2 possible outcomes in a coin: head and tail. Thus, the probability of getting a head in a coin is 1/2.
The probability of getting a 4 in a die and a head in a coin is 1/12.
(b) Let A be the event that the die comes up an odd number\nLet B be the event that the coin lands tail

There are six possible outcomes in a die: 1, 2, 3, 4, 5, 6. Since there are three odd numbers {1, 3, 5}, the probability of getting an “odd number” in a die is 3/6 or 1/2. There are 2 possible outcomes in a coin: head and tail. Thus, the probability of getting a head in a coin is 1/2.
The probability of getting an odd number in a die and a head in a coin is 1/4.
(c) Let A be the event that the die comes up an even number\nLet B be the event that the coin lands tail

There are six possible outcomes in a die: 1, 2, 3, 4, 5, 6. Since there are three even numbers {2, 4, 6}, the probability of getting an “even number” in a die is 3/6 or 1/2. There are 2 possible outcomes in a coin: head and tail. Thus, the probability of getting a tail in a coin is 1/2.
The probability of getting an even number in a die and a tail in a coin is 1/4.
(d) Let A be the event that the die comes up a prime number\nLet B be the event that the coin lands head

There are six possible outcomes in a die: 1, 2, 3, 4, 5, 6. Since there are three prime numbers {2, 3, 5}, the probability of getting a “prime number” in a die is 3/6 or 1/2. There are 2 possible outcomes in a coin: head and tail. Thus, the probability of getting a head in a coin is 1/2.
The probability of getting a prime number in a die and a head in a coin is 1/4.
(e) Let A be the event that the die comes up a factor of a 6\nLet B be the event that the coin lands tail

There are six possible outcomes in a die: 1, 2, 3, 4, 5, 6. Since there are four factors of 6 numbers {1, 2, 3, 6}, the probability of getting a “factor of a 6” in a die is 4/6 or 2/3. There are 2 possible outcomes in a coin: head and tail. Thus, the probability of getting a tail in a coin is 1/2.
The probability of getting a factor of 6 in a die and a tail in a coin is 1/3.
(a) What is the probability of drawing 3 red balls?\n(b) What is the probability of drawing 2 yellow balls?\n(c) What is the probability of drawing a red ball on the first and a yellow on the second?
Show Solution

There are a total of 8 balls. Since there are 5 red balls, the probability of getting a “red ball” on the first draw is 5/8. Before the second ball is drawn, the ball was returned and so the total of the balls in the jar remains. Thus, the probability of getting a “red ball” on the second and on the third draw is 5/8.
The probability of drawing 3 red balls is 125/512.
(b) Let A be the event that the first drawn ball is a yellow ball.\nLet B be the event that the second drawn ball is a yellow ball.

There are a total of 8 balls. Since there are 3 yellow balls, the probability of getting a “yellow ball” on the first draw is 3/8. Before the second ball is drawn, the ball was returned and so the total of the balls in the jar remains. Thus, the probability of getting a “yellow ball” on the second draw is 3/8.
The probability of drawing 2 yellow balls is 9/64.
(c) Let A be the event that the first drawn ball is a red ball.\nLet B be the event that the second drawn ball is a yellow ball.

There are a total of 8 balls. Since there are 5 red balls, the probability of getting a “red ball” on the first draw is 5/8. Before the second ball is drawn, the ball was returned and so the total of the balls in the jar remains. Thus, the probability of getting a “yellow ball” on the second draw is 3/8.
The probability of drawing a red ball on the first and a yellow ball on the second draw is 15/64.
